title: Counting Sidon Sets
description: Let f(N) be the max Sidon subset size and A(N) the number of Sidon subsets of {1,...,N}. Is A(N)/2^{f(N)} → ∞? (Yes) Is A(N) = 2^{(1+o(1))f(N)}? (No)

meta.author: Paul Erdős, Peter Cameron
originalContributions: Lean formalization of Sidon set definition
Saxton-Thomason and KLRS bounds as axioms

overview.historicalContext: This problem, posed by Cameron and Erdős, asks about counting Sidon sets (sets where all pairwise sums are distinct). It connects to additive combinatorics and the hypergraph container method. The problem appears as C9 in Guy's 'Unsolved Problems in Number Theory'.
overview.problemStatement: Let f(N) be the size of the largest Sidon subset of {1,...,N} and A(N) the number of Sidon subsets. Question 1: Is A(N)/2^{f(N)} → ∞? Question 2: Is A(N) = 2^{(1+o(1))f(N)}?
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines Sidon sets and the counting functions, then states the Cameron-Erdős questions and their answers as axioms. The current best bounds (Saxton-Thomason lower, KLRS upper) are included.
keyInsights: A Sidon set has all pairwise sums distinct (B₂ sequence)
Question 2: NO - the exponent is between 1.16 and 6.442, not 1+o(1)

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #861 (Cameron-Erdős problem on counting Sidon sets) is solved. Question 1 is answered YES (A(N)/2^{f(N)} → ∞). Question 2 is answered NO (the exponent is between 1.16 and 6.442, not 1+o(1)).
conclusion.implications: The hypergraph container method (Saxton-Thomason) provides powerful tools for counting combinatorial structures. The gap between bounds [1.16, 6.442] remains to be tightened.
openQuestions: What is the exact constant c such that A(N) = 2^{(c+o(1))f(N)}?
Can the bounds be improved beyond [1.16, 6.442]?
Does f(N) = √N + O(N^ε) hold for all ε > 0?
